title: Who will win the Republican primary for governor of Georgia in 2022?
preds: kemp is avg 20+ points ahead in all polls consistently; reporting over the weekend discussing how purdue's campaign is struggling
Kemp on track to win an absolute majority of the vote next week. Even if he is under 50% he will almost certainly win the runoff
most polls are consistently putting Kemp in the +/- 15-26 point range to win
Not much time left and Kemp is running away with it
No massive-enough missteps by incumbent Kemp during his current term.  Voters with easy voting access will seek continuity of protection from threats by liberal ideas.
Updating my forecast since there are only a few weeks left for Perdue to turn things around, and Kemp has widened his lead.
https://www.fox5atlanta.com/news/georgia-governor-gop-primary-kemp-leads-perdue-insideradvantage-pollThere's enough time left that I expect it may narrow a little bit, but Kemp will still win

AJC, the local paper, is talking about there being a chance Kemp can win without even a runoff. This has gone from close race, to potentially no contest. https://www.ajc.com/politics/ajc-poll-kemp-has-strong-shot-to-knock-out-perdue-without-a-runoff/MXKBVFQVYJHRXDEWBAR32QJWMA/
Updating my forecast based on recent polls. Perdue has had a chance to close the gap and he has not. It seems to have widened if anything.

Updating my forecast as we get closer to the first round and Kemp's lead seems maintained. I think it is deceptively large, as reflected in polls. People vote on fear and anger and I expect a strong showing from Kemp.
Trump is doing even more for Perdue but that doesn't seem to be working. Continuing to increase the chances of a Kemp victory in the primary.

https://twitter.com/bluestein/status/1514737884569518080 Landmark Communications poll of Georgia GOP gov race for 
@cbs46: 
Kemp 52%
Perdue 28%
Taylor 10%
Kemp up +10 in polls but poll movements and errors are lot more likely in primaries than in the general

Nate Silver made a good case about the base rate at which incumbent governors win re-nomination: 87%. That's actually a little lower than I expected. In any case, he says it's reasonable to count Kemp as the favorite, so I am tipping my scales in Kemp's favor now.
Many news pieces seem pessimistic on Perdue, but I think he still has a good shot at an upset based on voter grievances (anger, resentment) that tend to motivate primary voters.
Trump is doing what he can do rally for Perdue but that doesn't seem to be helping Perdue. Still two months for things to change but things seem to be slowly and steadily shifting towards Kemp

Kemp still seems to be in the polling lead pretty solidly on the R side of the house - however, Purdue is leading the polls when compared to Abrams (notionally D opponent) - Kemp likely also wins in a head-to-head but not by as much as purdue - so not sure if that could affect long term standing
I can't see anyone else winning this, and Kemp being the incumbent is enough to keep him there, 2-1 odds

The internecine war between Republicans means no matter which of the candidates win, the other will be limping into the general with Abrams. I think, so far, Kemp seems to be running hard and Perdue is on a leisurely stroll, expecting Trump's endorsement will do the work for him. I might have been less secure about this prediction last week, but Trump's inane and morally deviant praise for Putin has devalued his whole slate of candidates. Maybe in a blood red state or district, MAGA will still hold sway. But Georgia is no longer blood red.

Brian Kemp has the advantage of being the incumbent in a state where the top three executive positions are held by Republicans.  Incumbents historically have an electoral advantage for many reasons.  With strong candidates and a conservative base, it is unlikely that someone outside of the mainstream will be considered and would also make it difficult for a Democratic candidate to be elected for statewide office.
Giving the edge back to Kemp. It doesn't seem folks are aware of the Trump endorsement yet and it seems that might not be helping Perdue in all places.
I don't know why I put my "undecideds" into the "someone else" bucket. My heart hopes for the easily defeated Perdue, my head knows it will be Kemp. Probably.

tweaking up slightly based on an article from Forbes that was released about status of fundraising and current polling - signal for this (for me) is likely going to be tied to endorsements by other political figured and then correlation of increase/decrease in polls
quick review of current polling (for baseline) is showing Kemp in the lead (Quinnepac) with Kemp/Perdue being tied (Fox5) - leaning towards Kemp right now - but will be keeping eye on this election
Kemp has been doing a good job.
News and talking with friends who live in Georgia.
Trump endorsement aids Kemp; there is always some possibility of an unexpected candidate emerging.
People will by then came to their senses
Though currently trailing, the "new" Republican party will likely test their full abilities to challenge the left as harbinger for fall elections.

Having seen Trump throw his support behind Perdue and Vernon Jones bow out, I give the edge to Perdue over Kemp. Someone else could come roaring out of nowhere, too, especially if either top contender (ages 58 and 72) endure a serious health issue or accident.

-Kemp is the incumbent governor...from 1972 to 2021, there have been 21 losses by incumbent govs out of 391 primary elections, for an incumbent win rate of 94.6.
<https://smartpolitics.lib.umn.edu/2021/12/09/how-many-2022-gubernatorial-incumbents-will-fall-in-primaries/>
-From 2000-2018, only 6 incumbent governors lost primary reelections, and 2 of those were Lt govs who were elevated to gov due to vacancy...  <https://m.dailykos.com/stories/2014/4/20/1264682/-We-unlucky-few-A-look-at-the-incumbents-who-lost-their-primaries-1994-2012> This is my first ever forecast...i'm inclined to make this first forecast high in Kemp's favor, and look for reasons to push Kemp down as we get closer to May--events that occur similar to those which may have caused those 21 incumbent losers between '72 and 2021. I know lots of prognosticators are thinking Perdue will be a very strong challenge for Kemp, but Kemp has the momentum of history strongly in his favor.
starting out favoring kemp even without the trump endorsement, he has beaten abrams before while perdue lost his last election.

Kemp seems to be following the same playbook that Youngkin followed in Virginia: introducing a Parent's Bill of Rights and prohibiting schools from teaching critical race theory. The policies proved popular with suburban voters. Trump supported Youngkin, so Kemp seems to be appealing to the conservative base as well as potentially having the potential to win the governor's race. Kemp has $12 million in campaign funding. https://www.ajc.com/politics/politics-blog/kemp-reloads-campaign-coffers-as-he-prepares-for-2022/ORRGQ3CT6FC6LHMXAUMOYBQ4RY/ Perdue is a former Senator with $5.7 million to spend. https://www.opensecrets.org/news/2021/02/david-perdue-tries-again-2022/
Giving the edge to Purdue based on the recent Trump endorsement, but seems like a toss up at this point.
initial based on nothing based but gut feel and what my neighbors are saying, which is admittedly skewed towards "moderate" republicans
